definitions.definition: to be able to accept and deal with something unpleasant
definitions.sensetop: bear somethingbear doing somethingbear to do somethingbear somebody doing something

examples.text: The pain was almost more than he could bear.
She bore it all with her usual patience.
She **couldn't bear the thought of** losing him.
I can't bear having cats in the house.
He can't bear being laughed at.
He can't bear to be laughed at.
I **can hardly bear** to think about it.
How can you bear to eat that stuff?
I can't bear you doing that.
I just can't bear it any more!
Don't leave me alone. I wouldn't be able to bear it.
How can you bear this awful noise?
She couldn't bear seeing him so upset.
We could hardly bear to be outdoors in the blinding sunlight.

definitions.definition: to take responsibility for something

examples.text: She **bore the responsibility** for most of the changes.
Do parents have to **bear the** whole **cost** of tuition fees?
In the end it's consumers who **bear the burden** of higher prices.
You shouldn't have to bear the blame for other people's mistakes.
You must bear at least some responsibility for what has happened.

definitions.definition: to support the weight of somebody/something

examples.text: The ice is too thin to bear your weight.

definitions.definition: to show something; to carry something so that it can be seen

examples.text: The document bore her signature.
He was badly wounded in the war and still bears the scars.
She **bears little resemblance to** *(= is not much like)* her mother.
The title of the essay **bore little relation to** *(= was not much connected with)* the contents.

definitions.definition: to not be suitable for something

examples.text: Her later work **does not bear comparison** with her earlier novels *(= because it is not nearly as good)*.
The plan **won't bear** close **inspection** *(= it will be found to be unacceptable when carefully examined)*.
The joke **doesn't bear repeating** *(= because it is not funny or may offend people)*.
His sufferings **don't bear thinking about** *(= because they are so terrible)*.

definitions.definition: to have a feeling, especially a negative feeling

examples.text: He **bears no resentment** towards them.
He's **borne a grudge** against me ever since that day.
He's **borne me a grudge** ever since that day.
She **bore** him **no ill will**.

definitions.definition: to have a particular name

examples.text: a family that bore an ancient and honoured name

definitions.definition: to carry somebody/something, especially while moving

examples.text: three kings bearing gifts
Guests starting arriving, mostly bearing gifts.
He returned bearing a basket of vegetables.
Her two sons helped bear the coffin.
His parents had borne the child across the mountains.

definitions.definition: to move, behave or act in a particular way

examples.text: He bears himself *(= stands, walks, etc.)* proudly, like a soldier.
She bore herself with dignity throughout the funeral.

definitions.definition: to give birth to a child

examples.text: She was not able to bear children.
She had borne him six sons.

definitions.definition: to produce flowers or fruit

examples.text: These trees take a long time to bear fruit.

definitions.definition: to go or turn in the direction mentioned

examples.text: When you get to the fork in the road, bear right.

definitions.definition: to be a soldier; to fight
to have a successful result
to be a cause of difficulty or worry to somebody

examples.text: Taxation bears heavily on us all.
The burden of the tax bore most heavily on the poor.

definitions.definition: to remember somebody/something; to remember or consider that…

examples.text: You don't have to do anything about it now… just bear it in mind.
Here are some important points to keep in mind…
I'll keep what you say in mind.
Try to keep safety in the forefront of your mind at all times.

definitions.definition: to receive the main force of something unpleasant

examples.text: Schools will bear the brunt of cuts in government spending.

definitions.definition: to provide evidence of the truth of something

examples.text: The crowd of mourners at his funeral bore witness to the great affection in which he was held.
The ancient temples bear silent witness to the passing dynasties.

definitions.definition: to be realized by somebody, especially after a period of time

examples.text: It was gradually borne in on us that defeat was inevitable.

definitions.definition: to use energy, pressure, influence, etc. to try to achieve something or make somebody do something

examples.text: We must bring all our energies to bear upon the task.
**Pressure was brought to bear** on us to finish the work on time.

definitions.definition: to accept pain or bad luck without complaining

examples.text: There's nothing we can do about it. We'll just have to grin and bear it.

definitions.definition: to have a difficult problem that makes you worried or unhappy but that you have to deal with

examples.text: We all have our crosses to bear.

wordOrigin: verb Old English beran, of Germanic origin; from an Indo-European root shared by Sanskrit bharati, Greek pherein, and Latin ferre.
